0,654,0,650,There has been an enormous amount of positive local feedback - from a cross-section of local communities. In one sense, the &#039;stock&#039; of the Met has never been higher.<br />Stockwell was a significant set-back - but, for the most part, people have reacted in a reasonably balanced way and are genuinely appreciative of all that the Met is doing.<br />Effective communication and the flow of accurate information are critically important.

0,664,0,0,Legal Issues
0,665,0,650,Retaining community confidence requires information that can be rapidly transmitted to them on a borough. Information provided to boroughs that could be communicated was very slow in coming. The MPS need to provide a press bulletin for release to Boroughs<br />with even the most limited factual information within 60 minutes of an incident. Otherwise the 24 hour news channels will deliver their interpretation of the in incident and possibly damage community confidence. This message should be E mailed to SPOC&#039;s on Borough&#039;s for coordination and dissemination.
0,666,0,659,Insensitive action by some officers could lead to community violence - we don&#039;t want another Brixton or Broadwater Farm
0,667,0,0,Use of Independent Advisors
0,668,0,0,Command Structure / Information Flow
0,669,0,0,Issues for Management Board
0,670,0,662,Additional HVP at rail/underground/bus stations adds to community reassurance but also raises concern from some aspects of the community over any real value of the tactic ie what difference does it actually make to prevention/detection, whats the impact on priority crime due to resource abstraction from core policing etc

0,679,0,651,Lessons learned through allocation of FLO&#039;s at the earliest opportunity has contributed to positive support of bereaved families and not forgetting those injured.
0,680,0,662,The one size fits all approach to the Thursday 21st rail station operation was inappropriate and caused some raised fears in our communities. At some of the quieter stations the sight of a seven police officers caused some commuters to turn right around and go home as they thought a major incident had occurred. BOCUs should be left to make local operational decisons. If we had been told exactly what the purpose of the operation was we could have planned tactics to deliver it.
0,681,0,650,Timely and relevant information was required in a format that could be sent electronically to partners and community contacts. Other than press releases and transcripts other information had to be sanitised.
0,682,0,653,Personal visits to the local Mosque and Islamic Centre have been greatly appreciated - and have resulted in the development of some enormously positive local relationships.<br />Two &#039;Good Practice&#039; examples:<br />(1) 9th July - SMT visit to Islmic Centre following early evening prayers. Formal Q&amp;A session with local community members - with positive outcomes.<br />(2) 22nd July - Visit by female officers and staff (with interpreter) to Islamic Centre for Workshop with Moslem women. 0,684,0,655,The advent of 24 hour news channels and live interviews requires a different response from police. There needs to be a Police spokesperson accessing live broadcasts facilities even when full facts are not known. This will increase the risk of making a mistake by responding to current available information but allows access to a very wide population where even standard police appeals, contact numbers etc could be issued. It does not hyave to be a question and answer session as a matter of course.This will begin the process of getting a police message across and community reassurance messages at an early stage. Stilted interviews can damage the MPS image and a &#039;CADRE&#039; of spokepersons would be required and available.

0,693,0,650,Need for effective respone to allegations of Hate Crime.<br />Positive Example: On the evening of July 7th, a male was arrested in SW London for Racially Aggravated Criminal Damage and Common Assault. The incident took place in a small, Moslem-run supermarket - and was directly linked to the bombings that morning. The suspect was detained in police custody overnight and dealt with by the CSU the following morning. Charged and to court in custody. The court also remanded him in custody and he subsequently pleaded guilty. This sent a very strong - and extremely positive - message to the community, one that was very well received.
0,694,0,650,Community tension levels have remained consistently low on my borough. Regular community briefings shared with the Local Authority have taken place. The recent arrests have broadened the effected community to include Somali. Many positives arising out of this enhanced community contact with many groups gaining a better understanding of policing, especially stop and search.  Stop and search tactics are under scrutiniy from monitoring organisation, CRE in particular and it would help if the centre provide a lead on tactics to be used. Media have raised the issue of &#039;racial profiling&#039;.  Concern has been raised that all Asians could be seen as suspects regardless of faith.

0,858,0,668,The learning from this about information flow for me has been:<br />(i) Have a system to monitor requests to and from boroughs, this should be through a gateway (was eventually Emerald/Safer Neighbourhoods but should have been RVCTF<br />(ii) Manage the National Community Tension Team demands (who work on behalf of COBRA every 3 hours was too much;<br />(iii) Each borough to set up a single point of contact e-mail address so that generic requests can be sent out not just through borough commanders<br />(iv) Do NOT  abandon the role of link commander as their role is crucial in supporting and communicating with Boroughs.<br />(v) Establish a seperate tension team command structure with roles defined up to MB level<br />(vi) re-invigorate community intelligence and address how it will collated and disseminated on a daily basis.<br />(vii) Have a daily community briefing sheet from the start.

0,1234,0,1100,Ce dorim de la PROCURORI ?<br />- instrumentarea cazului pe baza informatiilor transmise de ofiterii de informatii;<br />- dupa analiza datelor furnizate de ofiteri si incadrarea lor juridica, sa solicite elemente de completare pentru pobarea infractiunii;<br />- autorizarea activitatilor specifice (perchezitie, constatare secreta, interceptarea comunicatiilor<br />- sa constituie si sa coordoneze echipa operativa (politisti, ofteri de informatii), prin atribuirea de sarcini specifice potrivit competentelor.<br />Ce dorim de la CONSILIERII JURIDICI ?<br />- incadrarea corecta a faptei (amenintarii) in cadrul legislativ existent;<br />- transformarea informatiilor obtinute in mijloace de proba, petru pastrarea conspirativitatii surselor;<br />- verificarea legalitatii activitatilor intreprinse;<br />- identificarea oportunitatilor de a actiona in cadrul legal pentru demescarea activitatilor ilegale ale suspectilor.

0,1241,0,1208,PENTRU PROCURORI<br />- stabilirea unor persoane cu rol permanent care sa asigure si sa se ocupe exclusiv dpdv procedural penal de cazul de criza cu care a fost sesizat, pina la finalizarea acestuia<br />- intelegerea locului/rolului valorii informatiilor furnizate si a modului de exploatare si valorificare a acestora in scopul evidentierii elementelor de natura a certifica existenta faptelor de natura penala sesizate<br />- dirijarea in  scopul obtinerii probelor si mijloacelor de proba relevante in caz<br />- solicitarea asistentei de specialitate pt a evita supraestimarea/subestimarea valorii informatiilor puse la dispozitie<br />PENTRU OFITERII DE INFORMATII<br />- cresterea calitatii si dirijarea corespunzatoare a surselor de informatii<br />- la solicitare/din proprie initiativa, sa se actioneze pentru obtinerea informatiilor relevante/certe/credibile, cu asumarea raspunderii pentru valoarea informatiilor furnizate

2,1300,0,0,Initial Call to the incident
1,1301,270,1300,I was in my office when a colleague told me there had been a train crash at Liverpool Street.
1,1302,265,1300,aware of confusion regarding the various calls - then heard the bomb on the bus go off and there was no doubt what had happened
1,1303,261,1300,Lying in bed at home when recieved phone call from partner who had been on tube and near the bus at time of explosions.
1,1304,267,1300,At FHQ and began the process of putting Gold Support function into place along with colleagues at FHQ
1,1305,217,1300,I was on train on way in to work. it got held at Ilford. i could only get as far as Fenchurch Street. walked around the corner to the Aldgate site and reported there for scene deployment.
1,1306,215,1300,Waiting for train on concourse at Kings Cross. Was told initially a fire had taken place on tube.
1,1307,212,1300,on the train into work for a middle turn when i was phoned and redirected to AHQ for an immediate briefing
1,1308,218,1300,Was on my way in to work when I was told LUL was shut down. On arriving at work was tasked to collect carriers along with the rest of the relief to collect other officers from out stations.
1,1309,226,1300,Attended Aldgate East station from Epping Lul and assisted MET setup cordons and road closure&#039;s around the station.
1,1310,253,1300,In the office, no specific direction or role given after incident. Most knowledge on what was happening was gleaned from SKY television news. Rest of that day was spent on &#039;reserve&#039;.
1,1311,219,1300,I was off duty at home, on annual leave, received information via media reports re incidents on underground trains. first reports power surges
1,1312,245,1300,Just left Liverpool Street station and saw several city of London officers running to station. heard of power problems on underground
1,1313,224,1300,i was on a train on the way to work, received a call from a member of my family to let me know the bombs had gone off at Liverpool Street. by the time I had arrived at work two more had gone off.
1,1314,220,1300,in scotland at the g8 conference.<br />next call at home asked to attend for flo duties.
1,1315,269,1300,Conducting normal duties and awaited deployment. Attended CLPS and deployed to Hendon re temp mortuary
1,1316,264,1300,i was working in the office and called to a briefing. i was tasked to set up a body reception centre in a hotel nearby.
1,1317,221,1300,i was woken by a phone call to come straight to Victoria ASAP. i put sky news on as i was getting ready and left in the car
1,1318,263,1300,acting DCS head of CID at FHQ - co-ordinating BTP Investigative response on 7/7 in terms of internal needs and dealing with external requests from MPS
1,1319,260,1300,i was attending the funeral of a neigbour when i heard it on the radio.my initial thoughts were here we go again as i was involved alot durinh Pira activities
1,1320,258,1300,phone call am8/7/05 from fhq requesting 3 officers to assist with mortuary duties. no other details given as to what these duties would involve.
1,1321,262,1300,i was on perternity leave and shopping at localtesco when i took a call from my wife explaining what had taken place. became very frustrated that i could not get into work to help out. Had a call that evening to parade the following morning at west ham.
1,1322,222,1300,i was playing golf and received a phone call asking if i was available for flo duties in london
1,1323,223,1300,I was at Aldgate responding to the initial call,there was confusion regarding the nature of the events.It soon became apparent what had happened and I delt with the walking wounded and cordons
1,1324,250,1300,central london enqs when i was informed of a tube crash
2,1325,0,0,What did you understand to be your role initially
1,1326,242,1300,At Kings Cross stn. wondering why the tube was shut. After walking to work and hearing the bus blow up from 1/2 a mile away spent the next 12 hours at work on stand by!.
1,1327,255,1300,in office the following day after 7th, anticipated Force involvement, cami prepared, volunteered. No idea what what volunteering for.
1,1328,218,1325,To transport officers to and from bomb sites.
1,1329,222,1325,family liaison officer
1,1330,215,1325,Assist in setting up Incident Room and checking availability of FLO&#039;s
1,1331,220,1325,flo duties to assist met.
1,1332,269,1325,I had no understanding of my role or the work to be undertaken at the Temp Mortuary
1,1333,261,1325,Unsure was on toil and made way to work to be deployed where ever I was required.
1,1334,260,1325,called in to work unsure of what would be required
1,1335,226,1325,Help any injured parties.  Assist clear the area and await instructions.
1,1336,265,1325,no initial direction
1,1337,250,1325,to be part of an investigation team
1,1338,263,1325,Co-ordinating BTP Investigative response
1,1339,262,1325,to conduct static patrols at central locations with other officers from West Ham.
1,1340,217,1325,At the time, I was preparing only for cordon duties at Aldgate. when i arrived, the rescue/recovery effort was in full swing. I was happy to play any role, however small.
1,1341,267,1325,To provide support to nominated Gold
1,1342,255,1325,Had no idea, neither did person sending me, only knew it involved mortuaty
1,1343,253,1325,No clear role given, no direction received. Asked to be considered if there was to be any involvement in mortuary work. Told that it would be sorted out following day
1,1344,221,1325,as a high profile high vis police prescence at the mainline stations prevention and protection
1,1345,264,1325,my role as stated was to set up a body reception centre at a local hotel.
1,1346,258,1325,Attend a briefing at Hendon re mortuary duties pm 08/7/05
1,1347,219,1325,Requested to attend btp hammersmith to standby, re potential Victim Recovery duties, once a clearer picture revealed extent of incidents
1,1348,245,1325,wnet to Liverpool st and then Aldgate to help with evacuation not given a specific role, wanted to help in any way.
1,1349,223,1325,I was aware that there may have been secondary devices and helped to set up cordons around the area to keep the public safe
1,1350,224,1300,i did not have an initial role until being instructed to attend the mortuary
1,1351,212,1325,my initial role was to attend waterloo station to conduct initial area search of both stations and organise resources for high profile security presence
1,1352,217,1332,I agree - when I was directed to the Mortuary the next day, I recieved no input as to what the next two and a half weeks would entail - what we would see, hear and smell.

They were sat in an office and had no contact with the victims &#039;families&#039; and made rash unfeeling decisions that would affect those bereaved for the rest of their lives.  I tried my best to make those terrible decisions better for the families.

Trying to make the best of the situation and not making things hard work. Being prepared to challenge SMT about issues in a group of people that I didn&#039;t know.

1,1978,311,1939,Getting on an underground train so soon after the bombing!<br />Also... not knowing what my role would be at the family assistance centre, being able to adapt myself into it. The first family i saw had clearly lost their mother. They were distraught and angry aimed at me and my colleague. I felt that despite no information what so ever when they left some hours later, they were calmer and had a better understanding of the difficulties wew were in. Some time later my colleague attended a memorial with that family. They apologised for being angry at us and thanked us for our support on day one!

More explantion to officers at scene&#039;s and hospitals of our excistence and why they should and shouldn&#039;t send people to us(FLO already deployed and no other issues, but expected more information, this raised the family&#039;s expectations). 1,3568,1095,2531,the principle comes from a piece of research from the criminological researcher Marion Fitzgerald - one of her practice papers during the Policing London research - and it is worth considering her quote in full:<br />&quot;It may be unrealistic to expect patrol officers:<br />- to exercise authority appropriately, with fairness and consideration for the feelings of others;<br />- to approach people with respect, regardless of their status;<br />- not to prejudge situations, but to listen;<br />- to see things from others&#039; points of view<br />if they themselves are not treated accoding to those principles. We need to think throuh the long term consequences if they continue to take the frustration that (double standard) can generate both into their personal lives (by which she is referring to the high levels of domestic violence amongst police officers that we do not like to think too much about) and out into the streets.

1,5528,1546,5511,Risk assessment when it comes to child protection looks at the risk to the individual ( the child, the investigator, the helper, the carer ) - the group ( the family, the team ) and the organisation ( the police, social services, health, education....et al )

1,5541,1544,5511,Is based on the known and what can reasonably be anticipated having considered that information. It is a constantly evolving process which must be centered around an individuals risk to personal harm.

1,5543,1548,5511,How to weigh the relative advantage/disadvantage in deciding to take (or not to take) action in any given situation
1,5544,1571,5511,Any review of danger to people or organisation with a view to taking action to minimise that danger. Can include physical dangers or danger to reputation.
1,5545,1574,5511,Risk is future - not past: It is what is foreseeable or anticipated and the overriding factor in determining risk is information. Once you have information you can determine its significance by attributing weight to it according to the circumstances.Therefore, the first step in any risk assessment is the steps taken to obtain information and then to give it some weight by evaluating it over time and in light of information you already have and information that emerges.
1,5546,1561,5511,risk is reduced through clarity of thought and direction to others

1,5548,1559,5511,Risk - a perception, based on experience and interpretation of data available or not available, of potentially undesirable outcomes. Risk in a policing context is invariably a negative, although in other areas in has a stronger association with opportunities as well as threats.

1,5560,1543,5511,Risk is a spectrum, not a static concept.  It refers to the judgement/ perception of likelihood of harm (mental, physical, emotional).  It is assessed, and its level is calculated by, the quantity/ type/ severity of known factors, and professional expertise and experience.

1,6030,1650,6007,All fax lines and lines into the casualty bureau are now international lines.  Despite repeated requests from CB it required an international incident before it was enabled!  It is established policy not to have live TV in the CB.  Callers to CB can hear it and it may appear unprofessional.  Also CB operators prefer not to be confronted with graphic images of what is happening at the scene whilst they are dealing with distressed callers.  Access to email can be facilitiated on request at any time.
1,6031,1653,6014,Future training - FLO logs should be in an electronic format (similar principle to HOLMES SIO log). It would assist me as an FLC to have access to logs for monitoring/supervision purposes and early ID of issues within the family which are documented can be viewed by FCO etc.  It could be searchable as a document and could be sent anywhere in the world quite easily!!

1,6080,1679,6014,There is some considerable confusion around DVI even amongst the experts,  DVI has a number of stands,  body recover,  mortuary and antemortem being crucial parts of DVI.  Currently there is national training around mortuary and body recovery however until now Ante-mortem sits within the ACPO strategy for Family Liaison .  If we are serious about proper DVI training we need to encompass all aspects of the training.  The question is what is a DVI trained team.  There is no such team yet in existence in the UK and there is no model for a DVI team.

1,6189,1655,5794,Prior to OP ROCK, I had no understanding of the chaos caused by a &#039;mass disaster&#039;. I had been on numerous murder incident rooms where one or maybe two people had been killed. These deaths by large had never caused a national reaction. Being involved in the investigation of an incident in another country and talking to survivors who had gone on hloiday to relax and ended up witnessing some of the most horrible scenes imaginable was an eye opener. I have developed my understanding of other agencies and the frustation that is involved when working in an international multi agency investigation, plus the aftermath that was left behind
1,6190,1678,6147,I successfully acheived respect and formed a strong relationship with the family I was depolyed with as an FLO. I am now also competent with the completion of the DVI forms and the collection of Anti Mortem  Data. I have gained a great deal of experience from working on this deployment, and feel that I would be an asset to any further, similar incidents to pass on my knowledge and experience.
1,6191,1674,6147,This was the first time I have worked in a family liaison role. Much of this ime was spent with the Annelie Vickers mum and step dad, taking statements and going through the DVI Process. This whole experience has made me aware how demanding an FLO Role is. It was nice to receive a letter from Anelie&#039;s mum thanking me and other officers for the part we played in Sharm. I would like to think that I displayed the necessary compassion which was required in the circumstances.<br />This was the first time I have worked abroad and I will never forget the experience. The worst part was working in the mortuary for a day, where we logged various body parts from 9 body bags.
1,6192,1667,6147,This was the first time I have had any experience as an flo<br />it was the first time i have completed dvi forms<br />it was the first time i have been deployed abroad<br />it was the first time i have done any mortuary work<br />it was the first time i have had experience of body parts<br />i showed great deal of versatility and flexibilty during my deployment<br />as i acted as a<br />flo<br />mortuary assistant<br />outside enquiry team officer<br />exhibits officer
1,6193,1649,6068,Op Rock developed me because I was able to adapt to various diferent roles within the Casualty Bureau basically being able to cover other peoples roles when required.  Utilising existing communication skills I was able to secure necessary essential equipment for other areas of the operation.  Having done the work as an FLO on Bracknell I was able to observe some of the difficulties from the Casualty Bureau side of things hopefully making me a more understanding FLO.
1,6194,1663,6147,The fact that I was a member of the west midlands police team, who never having experienced this form of incident, deal with the situation in a professional and compatent manner, adoted to a dynamic  situation and were able to provide help &amp; support to others.  The service should be duly credited with the display of professional commitment shown by it&#039;s staff
1,6195,1638,6147,I was fortunate enough to have gained experience in the role I performed in Op Rock during a previous deployment, I was also fortunate to have a supervisor who was prepared to listen and believe in my judgements but at the same time guide those judgements in the direction where they could be of most benefit to the overall aim of the task.<br />I feel that this has been both a great help in my personal development and would therefore greet any future challenge with enthusiasm.<br />It also channelled that expertise to the place where it  was of most value to the task in hand,  the test of this being the swift return of those we went to repatriate.
1,6196,1662,6147,from evidence and intelligence coming into the casualty bureau, I correctly identified those british nationals who were victims, at a very early stage. Next time I would know which documents to read in order to achieve the same result again, and the actions to raise as a priority, in order to do this.
1,6197,1679,6147,Flexibility<br />Upon deployment to Egypt I was uncertain as to what to expect and was nervous about the responsibility.  The team was selected through PNICC and I was working with total strangers who&#039;s skills and knowledge were unknown to me.<br />Its fair to say that whilst the skills and knowledge of the team did not cover the broader skills required by the DVI process they rose to the occaision carried out whatever role they were asked.<br />The training given is based on early adoption of systems of body recovery, mortuary work and ante-mortem gathering.  It was clear from the outset that these systems were not followed in Egypt.  The whole team worked together to adopt systems and methodology that would work under the conditions we faced.  We did not stray from our committment to find and ethically identify all of the deceased and strive to meet the expectations of their families.   In doing so we formed friendships with Embassy Staff and Egyptian professionals with whom I still receive contact.  As a consequence of our work some of the Egyptian Professionals have taken the time to review their own procedures on Mass Disaster
1,6198,1653,5732,Serious consideration has to be given to what the role of an FLO should be.  The basis for this is the fact that information coming from the Theseus and Bracknell feedback is the &#039;Gold&#039; standard is being set by the Met.  However, this would appear to be  without any wider consultation with other forces or organisations.  The continued engagement with a family is being asked to go on for a protracted period of time and some of these functions are merely to act as a mouth piece for the MIR.<br />An example is a document that comes from the Coroners department.  FLO&#039;s have been asked to circulate this to their family.This sets out the role, function etc of the coroner which is useful info.  It also has in there that if a family member would like to make a comment about their loved ones at the inquest they can OR an FLO will give it on behalf of them!  Who decided this?  The prime responsibility of an FLO is as an investigator.  ACPO must be very clear on this.
1,6199,1636,6178,Who viewed the deployment as a jolly? The conditions in Egypt were appalling and the team overthere worked tremendously hard. I am staggered that anyone could describe the deployment in such terms and it sounds like someone is terribly missinformed.
1,6200,1675,6147,I have gained a vast amount of experience in dealing with an incident of International importence.Liasion with outside agencies such as FCO,FSS and colleagues from other forces.I have gained a vast amount of knowledge of recording,movement and continuity of exhibits throughout the country which will stand me in good stead for any future operations/incidents.<br />I have also learned  about the various roles of my colleagues which has instilled in me that little bit more  patience and understanding of the difficult tasks that they perform and has put a brake on my impatience to get my job done and has made me  a better team player.I can say that i am proud to have been associated with the incident and staff of Op Rock.<br />PS get your exhibits in time.

1,6224,1650,6176,I would like to thank ACPO for the support they gave during the course of Operation Rock.  They asked questions, listened to the answers from experienced practitioners and were not afraid to make decisions based on available information.  The command structure was very much a two way street with a healthy respect for both sides.  I had the confidence that I could do my job with the necessary support in place for those occasions where I needed further guidance or strategic direction, without having to run to senior management every five minutes to gain ratification for any decisions I wanted to make.

1,6226,1653,6176,The role of the FLO needs to be re evauated in the light of these incidents. 1,7700,1798,7680,Trust is elusive in these events.  The community is not one set of answers or opinions.  Rather, it ranges from some segments that think we did not beat the suspect enough to those who think we were brutal vs those who think the actions were criminal and the only acceptable outcome is that the officers be immediately arrested and thrown in jail.<br />There is also an element within the department that believes that no cop in a critical incident can make a mistake that should result in discipline.
1,7701,1810,7680,thoroughness and need to act, sometimes quickly, may conflict with the need to take our time and fully examine an event. 1,7746,1801,7716,Investigators and advocates need to understand each others roles and recognize that at different points of the investigation and/or adjudication ownership and roles change.  During the investigation the advocates role is to support via advise and assistance (framing questions, allegations, etc.) and the investigators have primary ownership.  However, once the case goes to a Board of Rights the investigators need to shift to a support role and become an I/O, much like a homicide detective in a murder trial.<br />Most of our investigators are sergeants, and thus they are not as familiar with this concept as detectives are.  In this case, the detectives understood this better, and were less affected by the issues that arose between the investigators and the advocates.

Specialism within a field or experience within a community is vital to a professional service but can become introspective.  A course that widens the perspective of the individual and offers insight into alternative resposibilities would be of value.  This could involve community based projects or short term diverse responsibilities within the service.

1,8878,1885,8371,Our learning priorities are based on understanding individuals strengths and areas for development:: how individuals contribute towards the overal effectiveness of the team and how team efficency will determine the extent to which goals are achieved.
1,8879,1885,8878,To achieve these aims the candidate will be presented with scenarios which challenge team dynamics , they will centre around  :<br />Setting standards(leadership principles)<br />Communication(debriefing feedback)<br />managing conflict.<br />personal development(coaching mentoring and training)<br />praising and acknowleding achievement.
1,8880,1885,8878,Methodology<br />Student will form small syndicate groups with a mix of skills .where the scenario will be discussed , options for esolution identified and actions decided upon.<br />Group presentations to the class.<br />Feedback invited .
1,8881,1885,8878,By adopting this methodology the students will not only deal with the interactive scenario.<br />As a syndicate they will embody team working by sharing skills and values and supporting each other.<br />The class as a whole wil also operate as a team through debriefing.<br />The facilitators will summarise learning and reinforce values and service policy as required.

1,10056,2134,10046,A simple, training programme for Officers and other emergency services personnel attending the scenes of disaster incidents. Further to this to develope the basics for responding to such incidents.  My Police Force is too small for the time to deal with proactive work (intelligence) on terrorism.  However theoretical lectures on proactive work should be delivered.  For this we are much depended on assistance from other countries.  And for this the programe will be including lectures on how should we liaise with other agencies etc.

1,12508,2956,12482,Extradition has always been regarded as an act of State and it therefore engages both the judiciary and the executive. The final surrender is generally an executive act. The basic tenet of extradition is double criminality, this relates both to the conduct and jurisdiction. So, the Conventions provide the basis for extradition (where there is no general arrangement between the requesting/requested state) - in order to comply with such a request, extradition can only be granted for the mischief being addressed in that convention and not any other general offence of terrorism. Further, both states must recognise the same extra-territorial jurisdiction, if that is appliacable. Therefore, if that is not the case, no extradition can follow; which means the Convention has failed to achieve its intention. Where however a general arrangement/treaty is in existence between two states then the offence must be an extradition offence in order for the request to be processed - does this help?
1,12509,2862,12482,i don&#039;t understand this comment - elaborate
1,12510,2862,12509,ok

1,12518,2956,12495,regrettably no. If I may let me illustrate this by way of a case exampe: Algeria sought the extradition of a suspect accused of terrorism from the UK. As there is no treaty between Algeria &amp; UK, we had to rely on the Montreal Convention. On examination of the request it transpired that the accused was wanted for an act of terrorism which included the Montreal Convention offences - consequently the UK had to refuse to surrender. At the same time, the extradite/prosecute principle collapsed as we could not get the evidence from Algeria. So suspect is in UK with no prospect of extradition or prosecution - safe haven??
1,12519,2862,12513,The security council resolutions dealing with terrorism are made under Ch 7 of the UN Charter, which all states have agreed to be bound by. So there are some international duties to cooperate, but I also do not know whether we are obliged to cooperate informally on terrorist offences
1,12520,2862,12516,Its not really about sanctions for not ratifying - its about seeing your own national interest in this, or understanding international cooperation as in everyone&#039;s interest
1,12521,2862,12501,European Convention countries will not under their convention extradite someone to a country practicing the death penalty, without assurances that the DP will not be carried out even if imposed
1,12522,2956,12501,There is a prohibition on the return of fugitives or providing mutual legal assistance where the requesting state has the death penalty, unless the requesting state provides an assurance that the death penalty would not be invoked. This has not posed a great deal of difficulty as States are generally content to provide such an assurance. However a refusal to provide an assurance will lead to a refusal of assistance/surrender of fugitive!
1,12523,2958,12493,Informally obtained evidence can be used in court.the general principle asto whether informal or formal request is needed is whether a coercive power is to be exercised in the requested state; eg, search andseizure will require formal request; interview of suspect will require a formal request etc. But care needed re: informal request: ensure that execution of request is lawful under requested state&#039;s law.
1,12524,2862,12512,I think the US also gets attention for death penalty - it may not feel like if from here; sometimes the criticism is about mandatory sentence of death where the courts cannot hear evidence in mitigation
1,12525,2862,12490,It is a basic principle of this area of law that you either try the person yourself or render him to others who wish to try him; what relevance if he is a national or not?
1,12526,2958,12484,Re: MLA: yes; but it needs to be drafted wider than &#039;treaty&#039; so as to cover arrangements and schemes (such as The Harare Scheme) . In fact, a fairly straightforward piece of domestic legislation can address both outgoing requests and execution of incoming requests. UNODC is about to publish its model law on MLA (there has been Com Sec input).
1,12527,2956,12513,Extradition is an act of State and is therefore entitled under international law to refuse a request for extradition. This is reflected in all the extradition treaties/conventions under the general heading of &#039;grounds for refusal&#039;. The UN Conventions silently acknowledge the right of State to refuse to extradite and hence the &#039;poltical offence&#039; exception is specificlly set out.<br />In so far as mutual legal assistance is concerned, there are grounds for refusal but these are narrower than extradition requests.<br />In relation to the cooment on Chapter VII - the position is as follows: The SC has required States to sign/ratify and implement the CT Convention. UNSCR 1373, in particular spells this out; however that resolution went further and required states to criminalise the offences of terrorist financing (the offences are contained in the body of the resolution). In essence, therefore the SC has mandated States to criminalise CT offences and provide a framework for international co-operation; but it does not demand that States cannot refuse to assist. So looking at it from a narrow legal perspective there is no contravention of international law if States refuse to assist/extradite; but as the comment states there are international duties that states have taken on which places them under an obligation.
1,12528,2862,12486,It will depend on their own law; but if the person is physically present in your area, you can assert jurisdiction (if you decide not to extradite to the place where the act took place) - this will require obtaining evidence from the place where the act took place
1,12529,2958,12513,Re: MLA and informal requests:<br />An MLA request for evidence can be made even in the absence of a bilateral or multilateral. However, the requested may decline to assist. In doing so, it will be acting within its rights. An informal request for intelligence can also be made, but, again, may be refused.
1,12530,2956,12512,The US, like any other State that retains the death penalty must provide an assurance to the requested state - to this end they are in no different position to any other state. Let me illustrate this by an example - the US sought the extradition of individuals believed to be involved in the Embassy bombings in 1998. The extradition request has still not been complied with despite assurances regarding the death penalty as the defence submit that they can&#039;t be trusted! Proceedings are therefore still ongoing some 7 years after the request was first submitted!
1,12531,2958,12515,Lack of reciprocity in that example simply because of odd position that UK does not allow evidential use of UK intercept (intel only), but UK courts do allow adducing into evidence of intercepts from other states. Hence, can make the request, but problems complying with an incoming request.
1,12532,2863,12480,How would one deal with a continous offence, where it has been perpetuated in more than one jurisdiction, would all the States have jurisdiction to try that person for basically the same offence?
1,12533,2956,12486,The Conventions recognise 2 bases - territorial &amp; active personality test (nationality of offender but States can assert jurisdiction of the grounds of nationality of victim (passive) and national security. However, one must remember that a State cannot exert exorbitant jurisdtion which violates international law. The 1925 ICJ decision in the Lotus case confirms this principle. Jurisdiction as I mentioned earlier is inextricably linked to State practice and is subject to development; it is a living concept.
1,12534,2958,12504,Not on that ground alone. Similarly, where common law states have taken active personality jurisdiction, the national being prosecuted will not be successful in challenging only on the ground that the offence took place outside the jurisdiction, since that would defeat the basis of jurisdiction which has been taken. However, there may be other grounds of challenge: eg, both civil law and common law jurisdictions have &#039;double jeopardy&#039; protection.
1,12535,2956,12497,A33 of The Refugee Convention sets out the non-refoulment principle. Where a person has been granted political asylum it is unlikely that an extradition request would succeed. However practical approaches can be considered such as trying the person in another part of the requesting state; but this will depend on the basis of the grant of asylum
1,12536,2956,12496,I wonder if you would be so kind as to clarify what you mean by &#039;which country gets his access&#039;?
1,12537,2876,12531,this seems to amount to encouraging safe havens as the UK has taken a hypocritical stance

1,12539,2956,12532,Evey state affected can claim jurisdiction, and this where international co-operation becomes most effective. Therefore, prosecutors &amp; law enforcement agencies of the affected States would negotiate the most appropriate venue for prosecution - this is what is loosely termed as &#039;jurisdiction shopping&#039;
1,12540,2956,12514,wholly agree with your observation. The issues of laws of war and international humantiarian law are quite distinct from what we are considering in this workshop.
1,12541,2862,12497,The asylum process must run its course - extradition proceedings will normally be on hold until this time

1,12544,2956,12487,You must show jurisdiction as it is the basis of justiciability, in that national courts cannot try offences unless they are justiciable under national law.
1,12545,2862,12498,These are two separate issues - high seas, and stateless persons.
1,12546,2958,12537,Certainly at odds with position in most other states. Rationale is that by keeping non-evidential there will not be disclosure of methodology and extent or otherwise of tapping will not be revealed. Conversely, &#039;foreign&#039; intercept, from a State which allows evidential gathering, will not engage the same public interest and so can be used in evidence in the UK.<br />Likely that UK&#039;s position will change in the future to bring itsapproach more in line with that of other States.

1,12550,2956,12500,Offences committed on an aircraft - here the State in which the aircraft is registered has deemed extended jurisdiction and can therefore properly try the matter
1,12551,2956,12502,where an offence is committed in territorial waters; the coastal state enjoys jurisdiction.
1,12552,2956,12549,Airside is a lot more complicated because you have a combination of being in the country but not entered the country - generally speaking the consensus is that airside is excluded as the person has not entered the country; so in a recent incident a person for whom a warrant was issued remained on the aircraft having learnt of the warrant, and this could not be executed as the aircraft was registered in another country (&amp; that country enjoyed deemed extended jurisdiction) - does this assist?

2,12709,3016,0,How do you manage community intelligence
2,12710,3016,0,What measures do you have in place to enable early intervention?
1,12723,2991,12715,Yes. Measures that intefere with privacy must be lawful, covered by legal authority, particularly if the objective is evidence [not just intelligence] (body searches, bugging, phone tapping, correspondence, use of undercover agents).<br />As far back as 1978, the European Ct of Human Rights in Klass v Germany accepted that in order to deal with the threat from highly sophisticated terrorist activity, &quot;the Court has to accept [as compatible with the right to privacy] the existence of ... some powers of secret surveillance .. as necessary in exceptional circumstances in a democracy for the prevention and detection of disorder&quot;,<br />However, the Court noted that because these forms of surveillance and interception are &quot;a serious inteference with private life&quot;, it is essential to have and to follow clear and precise rules, to have judicial supervision initially and periodically, and not to give investigating authorities &#039;carte blanche&#039; - the fear (at the extreme end) is that we find we live in a &#039;big brother&#039; society where none of our personal life is truly private.

1,12728,2991,12709,This is what I mentioned in relation to human rights-based approaches to policing and community relations - John&#039;s presentation clearly highlights the significance of the community as a source of intelligence and cooperation.<br />Policing practices (arbitrary arrests, searches, abuse of powers, excessive use of force, no plan of outreach, violations of basic rights) can destroy community relations leading to cycles of distrust. This is what I meant by police not waiting for community to change its view of police - the police need to make a bridge. &quot;Human rights-based policing is right in principle / law - and it works, it makes the police officer&#039;s job easier in the community, it helps in the investigation of criminal activity.<br />All terrorists must eventually live in the community. If relations are poor with the community, and no culture of talking cooperation and reporting, detection will not take place.

1,12732,2991,12717,Due process is key here - it is vital that police and prosecutors avoid &#039;short cuts&#039; and see very early on the legal hurdles and procedures that are necessary, and deal with these.<br />In the long term, there is a need to avoid undermining or abusing our own systems in response to threats from terror and crime

1,12741,3013,12738,no right should be absolute!
1,12742,2991,12733,Yes, see the comments on the first point - about community intelligence
1,12743,2991,12741,Rights are not absolute. Look at the ICCPR in your folder, for example, or at Article 29 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. In the ICCPR, each right is qualified by limitations - for example &quot;everyone has freedom of expression&quot; (Art 19(1)) but this is limited see Article 19(2) - the right &quot;may be subject to certain restrictions ... as provided for by law and as necessary...for respect of the rights and reputations of others...for the protection of national security, public order, public health, or morals&quot;. So, the right to freedom of expression (like other rights) is not unlimited - this is a misconception. The right to freely express oneself by making videos is limited by public morals requirements for example forbidding child pornography.<br />It is very important to break down myths about rights with law enforcement officials, so as to get them to see these as simply part of the framework or environment in which they live and work. Rights do not threaten their job.
1,12744,2980,12710,periodic meetings/briefings amongst enforcement agencies-
1,12745,2991,12722,See comments below on &#039;balancing&#039; - the freedom of expression is limited by balancing it with protection of the public from incitement to hatred and violence
1,12746,2991,12718,This is an issue - recall the need to decide very early on intelligence and evidence and bearing in mind the diference between the two
1,12747,2981,12709,Through the efforts of community policing    intelligence led-policing
1,12748,2980,12709,respect and example
1,12749,2991,12730,Yes - this is also related to community relations more generally. The manner in which random searches are done can put the public off, if they are not sensitively done. In the same way, great care needs to be taken with searches of homes - the starting point is always that person&#039;s privacy is to be respected UNLESS there is a lawful reason for search of person or property.
1,12750,2991,12734,It is true that the wider issues of religious tolerance and diversity (which raise issues of human rights, non-discrimination, equality), these issues feed into the wider terrorism debate. Of course, religion can be hijacked and abused. But lack of respect for people&#039;s religious rights can inflame situations, leading to recruitment etf
1,12751,2991,12735,See the ICCPR and American Conventions in the folder - non-discrimination and equal treatment before the law are central to a rights-based response. Systematic patterns of discrimination against groups of persons, as well as being wrong, is likely to make policing and intelligence gathering much more difficulty.
1,12752,2991,12737,See ICCPR and American Convention provisions dealing with freedom of association and freedom of assembly. This relates to the &quot;balance&quot; between liberty and security  - how much do we affect people&#039;s ordinary lives while trying to protect them? Over the long term, how does a blunt response to threats lead to a very different looking society to the one we want? Now, some of these are big, philosophical issues - but the challenge is to get officers to see their own conduct as part of a bigger picture, and to consider the consequences of their conduct in the longer term

1,12821,3097,12785,If the trawler is in territorial waters, then there is no concern about stopping &amp; searching the vessel
1,12822,3103,12783,-1st Search outside territorial waters, 2nd search inside territorial waters<br />- Was there a right to search the first time?<br />-Issue of drug transaction conducted on high seas, issue of illegality<br />-Customs has search &amp; arrest powers based on reasonable suspicion - Criteria satisfied : Trawler assumed to be speeding out of territorial waters into international waters, then forced to return to territorial waters where 2nd search conducted<br />-nature of the detention/questioning done on the trawler - Was due process followed?<br />-No Caution given<br />-Use of promise, threat, coercion may affect admissibility of statement
1,12823,3104,12779,The initial search ocurred on the high seas, and if there is in place a bi-lateral or mutilateal agreement in place then the stop and search of the vessel would be approprite, but genereally if this is not the case the stop would be valid but not the search.
1,12824,3097,12785,If the vessel is boarded in the High Seas the B would have jurisdiction in any event. However if A has a national on board the vessel, then if A has extra-territorial active personality  jurisdiction, then they too have jurisdiction.
1,12825,3104,12779,any contraband found during the initial search would be subject to challenge if used fro evidential purposes
1,12826,3104,12779,UNCLOS would be relevant
1,12827,3103,12786,-Authorisation from Home Minister is legitimate only if he has such authority<br />- Informal relationship does not affect passing of intelligence but tipoff would not be admissible<br />- Usually in C&#039;bean territories a Magistrate/Judge has such authority on an application made to him<br />-HR Issue Violation of right to Privacy which is guarded by constraints applied<br />-Intercepts products are admissible if proper authority was obtained, ie if Minister is competent authority
1,12828,3103,12789,- It can be admissible if the request was made formally, based on evidence the request was made informally<br />-Prosecutor in A will have difficulty only if he intends to use it - he may not need it
1,12829,3101,12784,1. Yes it gives a cause of concern because of the foreign currencies and cocaine found in the vessel and if it would be within the jurisdiction of A to search<br />2. yes, the intercept products are admissible, provided the Home Minister authorising the interception is the competent authority governing laws relating to interception of communication  but it has human rights implication as it relates to invasion of privacy
1,12830,3097,12785,There is no indication that the trawler is flying the flag of another State, and so a presumption can be made that the vessel is registered in A - this would permit the initial boarding &amp; searching.
1,12831,3104,12779,Subject to the existence of a multi lateral or bi-lateral agreement or treaty such as the &#039;Shiprider agreement&#039;, the second search of the vessel in territorial waters would have to conform to the standards set for stop and search of vessels.<br />Any contraband found in these circumstances would be subject to the provisions of these agreements.
1,12832,3103,12792,- No formal method for authorising participator<br />- On the face of it mere permission from Inspector is adequate<br />-Issue of Accountability of the Inspector giving permission<br />-Undercover agent is Agent Provacatuer- is there legal underpinning to protect him and evidence obtained through him?<br />-UC&#039;s activities has no parameters - no clear guidelines, hence no idea whether he will get immunity for acts done<br />-Does providing the truck etc. invlove him beyond redemption<br />-his activity in the organisation has to be balanced by his need to get the trust of Totalia<br />-In light of fact that there are no parameters, it is difficult to say if he has gone too far
1,12833,3097,12788,Jamaica - judicial warrant must be obtained &amp; product is admissible<br />Bahamas - commissioner of police   AG must consent - product is admissible<br />Antigua - no provisions for intercept<br />Belize - we think that there are no provisions for intercept
1,12834,3101,12790,Yes it will cause difficulties as the evidence may not be sufficient to prove the identity of the person whose conversation has been intercepted and it depends on further co-operation from B.
1,12835,3104,12779,The intercept products would be admissible depending on the legislative regime of &#039;A&#039;.<br />Human Rights issues: The permission granted  was granted by the Home Affairs Minister, which appears valid.  However, the granting of the authorisation for an indefinite period would be in violation of Sam&#039;s human rights<br />Also he intercept for such a large group is too wide, because it violates the individual&#039;s right to privacy
1,12836,3104,12780,Please see the above
1,12837,3104,12781,It will because it is insufficient information to properly prosecute the matter.<br />&#039;A&#039; should make a request for a full and frank disclosure of all information held by &#039;B&#039;
1,12838,3104,12782,Because there is no formal method for authorising UC, and permission is assumed to have been granted by the relevant officer,  the deployment appears to be within bounds of the policy, which governs such matters.
1,12839,3101,12793,No he did not go too far (the reasoning would be explained in the plenary as there was difference of opinion)
1,12840,3097,12788,HR considerations:<br />Rights engaged are:<br />right to privacy<br />re length of interception if it is reasonably required and investigation is complex, interception is not a problem provided it is subject to periodic review;<br />collateral intrusion - if the lines are duly authorised then there is no impediment to the use of the intercept.

2,12842,3122,0,Message 1
1,13061,3147,12846,0925 Message 2 - SIO<br />I assume tactical command of this incident in Central 3000.<br />The primary objective is the preservation of life.  The prosecution of offences and all other objectives are secondary to this.<br />The SO13 call-out team with assistance from SCD operational teams are conducting the following priority actions on my behalf:<br />Debriefing the two  witnesses to ascertain full accounts and descriptions<br />Conducting a CCTV capture at both LT stations and on the route apparently taken by the silver hatchback and viewing this material.<br />Liaising with LT staff re Oyster card usage by the suspects to track their movements<br />Ensuring that any images available - including those from the witnesses mobile-camera - are assessed in terms of suitability for facial recognition software and also circulated to all who may be able to assist with providing possible idents.<br />The original incident has been subject to a hot debrief in liaison with all relevant stakeholders and I am satisfied that all immediate actions have been taken in terms of alerting all potential stakeholders and partner agencies to the possible threat posed by these individuals and ensuring that any available information relevant to this ongoing situation is passed to C3000 for assessment.<br />I have also actioned the briefing of CO19 and surveillance teams from SO12 and SCD and requested a Tac Advisor and Surveillance Commander to be deployed here to C3000 also
2,12846,3122,0,Message 2
1,13064,3147,12842,0915 Message 1 - Intelligence Unit<br />Intel cell opened at 0915hrs on authority of Commanders SCD/CT in response to CAD 5239 of today.<br />Staffing:<br />SCD7 -  DS (Co-ordinator), DC (Controller), Analyst and 2 intel development officers<br />SO13 - Analyst, 1 intel development officer, 2 SPOC officers<br />SO12 - 2 DCs<br />Precis of events thus far:<br />At approx 0830hrs this morning, Mr Adeyemi OLUWESU - a security guard at an office complex  in PARK CRESCENT, W1 - has contacted IR saying that he has seen a silver hatchback vehicle pull up in the street where he is posted.   Mr OLUWESU has witnessed four men get out of the vehicle and proceed to decant yellow liquid from a large container in the boot into separate, smaller bottles which each man has then placed at least one of into his rucksack.  The vehicle was driven by an IC1 female who appeared to give each man a slip of paper before driving off towards REGENTS PARK immediately.<br />Mr OLUWESU was very concerned about this behaviour and took camera-phone images of the suspects in the street.  The four then split into two groups of two and he followed one pair through a nearby park to the REGENTS PARK LT station where they were seen to enter using Oyster cards.  One of the two (referred to below as Subject 1) was seen using a mobile phone as he was followed by the informant.<br />Mr OLUWESUs fellow security guard on duty, Mr Ian BRADSHAW, followed the other two men to GREAT PORTLAND STREET LT station where they also entered and were lost from sight.<br />This incident was declared an OPERATION ANDROMEDA by IR and lasted approximately 30  minutes  before the two groups were lost into the tube network without further trace at about 0900hrs.<br />The five subjects were described by the witnesses as follows:<br />Driver - Female, IC1, late 20s, dark hair wearing a Muslim headscarf.<br />Subject 1 - Male of Somalian appearance, a/age 30 yrs wearing a<br />black parker coat and black trainers.<br />Subject 2(*) - Male of East European appearance, a/age 30 yrs wearing a dark blue hooded sweatshirt and dark jacket, black trousers and dirty white trainers<br />(* This male was seen to travel in the front passenger seat and spoke to the female before parting.)<br />Subject 3 - Male of Somalian appearance a/age 25 - 35 yrs<br />Subject 4 - Male of East European appearance a/age 25 - 35 yrs<br />Subjects 1 and 2 were followed by Mr OLUWESU into REGENTS PARK LT and Subjects 3 and 4 were followed by Mr BRADSHAW into GREAT PORTLAND ST LT (no clothing descriptions at this stage of the latter pair).  Both guards witnessed the fluid being poured out by the subjects and the group were described as purposeful and aware of their surroundings throughout.  Mr BRADSHAW believes that the men he followed were suicide bombers.<br />There are no immediate indications as to the whereabouts of the five subjects at this stage.

He has then entered the tube system at Elephant and Castle LT.  On what appears to be his last journey of the day on several occasions during the period he appears to be making a return journey along this route exiting the tube at the Elephant and Castle and boarding a 53 bus eastbound.<br />The inference is that the user resides near the bus stop that he uses in the mornings;  ie. the area of OLD KENT ROAD<br />Analysis of this data continues.

If this is the case, certainly TATP versions are known to be highly volatile; although in terms of risk to the public, much depends on the mix, volumes, concentration, containment and possible fragmentation/shrapnel features of whatever has been constructed.<br />For information only at this stage: a recent search of a hotel room in Northern England found a rucksack with a plastic bucket of yellow liquid in it left behind by the room occupiers.  Fast-time work conducted by the Intel team at the time found that the persons who had rented the room had pre-cons for fraud offences and when tested this fluid transpired to be that known to be used in so-called Black money scams.<br />1047 hrs<br />Location of bus stop passed to SO12 and BSS for assessment re any possible known North-East African subjects residing in this area. 1,13317,3453,12969,^DSO<br />Three options<br />(1) Dynamic entry<br />(2) Containment and call out<br />(3) Intervention upon them leaving the address of their own volition.<br />The preferred/agreed option of both SIO/DSO is for dynamic entry. This is preferred because (1) it provides the safest option for the public and for the officers who will be detaining these people;(2)it is most likely to allow prevention of detonation of any device at the address (i.e. insufficient time to prepare devices (3) it allows the greatest opportunity for the preservation of evidence<br />Other address identified will also be subject to dynamic entry to secure evidence and arrest any outstanding suspects.<br />Contingency Plans are developed for compromise of the dynamic entry, the contingency is to revert to containment &amp; call out.<br />Further contingency plans have been developed for individuals leaving the premises and I have taken tactical advice &amp; have decided to use the Pluto option of containment &amp; challenge.<br />I am of the opinion that these options provide the greatest opportunity for a safe and successful resolution of this incident achieving the primary aim of safety to the public. I believe that the options that I have chosen are proportionate to the intelligence picture that I have at this time, provided by Silver SIO, the actions I have authorised are legal, I am accountable and the this action is necessary in order to disrupt potential activity and safeguard the public.

1,19184,4489,19123,1 have one person talking to them. They should only ask open questions. Do not approach them to near say about 15 yards. you do not want your officer grabbing them and going over with them. Advise the officer to ask them to come down the stairs with him and to talk there.<br />You need an  intelligence cell or at least one person in charge of intelligence so that you can get some background on them. It would help if we knew who they were and what there were actually upto.<br />You need to cordon the area off and treat this as a critical incident. Inform the duty officer. Get paramedics to the scene.

1,19193,4489,19132,We need to take our time. We need to build a rapport and try and get them talking. I agree we cannot rush them. I suggest we only use two negotiators and only one will speak with them. We should stand as far away as possible so as to reduce the pressure on them. we still do not know why they are here or what there intention is. They may just be attention seeking, or this may actually be a suicide pact. We will attempt to build a rapport and then seek to use influence to get the to defer any action they may be considering.

1,19202,4489,19142,At this point I would advise not to give them water. The fact that they have asked for it is a good sign in that people who are planning death are inlikely to ask for food or water to sustain them. On the other hand this may prolong the negotiation and allow us to get a better rapport with them. I advise against giving the water to them where they are but have it here on the roof where they can see it and invite them away from the edge when we will give it to them. Better still put the water on the ground floor where they can see i

1,19279,4494,19132,What is the strategy fro the incident?<br />Assuming saving life and return to public normality -<br />To ask them what they are doing there.<br />Find out the level of risk they pose to themelves or others.<br />Seek to establish if they are willing to come to safety - use active listening and emotional labelling to establish rapport, gain trust and seek to influence them to choose a safe resolution.<br />Define intel. requirements -<br />Knowledge of the people, history, use of drugs or alcohol and any mental illness.<br />Find family/friends fro further info.
1,19280,4493,19132,Police officer who has engaged them in conversation will introduce negotiator(s) (preferably 2) who will begin to engage with the two on the roof.  Strategy is to engage them with a view to<br />1)  Encourage them to come down safely<br />2) Identify why here and why now - what is this about?<br />3) Identify any intelligence opportunities<br />4) Provide information to the incident commander for consideration of other tactical options

1,19306,4494,19141,Ask them if they will come to safety for the water.<br />If not, ask them if they need any medicines or food as we are worried they might slip and fall.<br />I would agree to give them the water.<br />I would describe how we give it to them carefully - we should agree that we will move forward, place it near to them and withdraw. If the decision is not to try to grab them, this should be made clear and promised to them.<br />I would ask if food is approved and offer it to them to enduce reciprocity
1,19307,4492,19141,THe chance to have water could mean that they become more comfotable and may lengthen the time they are prepared to stay in position. Conversely it shows that we are giving them something to help them in their situation. It is early in the incident to provide them with a demand and may be an option to deny it at this stage but consider it for later on.
1,19308,4493,19141,Giving them some water may encourage a response and encourage them to engage in converstaion.  It is part of Maslow&#039;s Hierarchy of Needs, and likely to bring them into the Social Needs&#039; tier, and therefore more likely to engage with negotiators.  Agreeing to give them some water may also buy more time to develop the behavioural stairway of active listening, empathy, rapport, influence and change of behaviour.  Providing water will build on rapport.  At this stage they are not offering much information, therefore providing water seems reasonable.

1,19362,4493,19159,The use of an intermediary is a high risk tactic.  At this point we do not know what this is about or why this girl is in this position. My advice at this stage is to debrief sister about all she knows about her sister and why she may be here today and look to utilise any intelligence.  I can task negotiators with letting girl know her sister is here and exploring their relationship in order that a more informed decision can be made on introducing sister into the negotiations.

1,20612,4799,20518,To be treated as a Cat B murder.<br />Key witnesses to be interviewed, statements to be obtained, clothing to be seized.<br />Forensic opportunities clear, consideration of support from specialist experts in terms of blood distribution.<br />CCTV in locality - assessment of CCTV opportunities<br />H2h parameters to be identfied and set<br />Consideration of extending initial scene to include railway property<br />Press startegy - likely to be press interest - a opportunity to make a witness appeal and potentially identify movements of victim and other witnesses not yet known/identified<br />Review MFH reports etc in an effort to identify offender<br />Possible robbery motive? - Explore similar reported offences and reasecrh with a view to identifying patterns and trends of offending in area of offence<br />Source tasking to b considered<br />MIR to be set up<br />FLO to be considered together with other k<br />key roles
1,20613,4800,20518,Establish a number of strategies that will support me in establishing: who the victim is, how he came to be at that location, how he sustained the injuries, what was the cause of death and if relevant who is responsible.<br />These strategies will be based around and overarching Investigation strategy incorporating the following:<br />Victim<br />Scene/Forensic<br />Witnesses<br />Suspects<br />Intelligence<br />Fast Track HP Actions<br />CCTV<br />Media<br />Resources
1,20614,4805,20518,I am the SIO. I have been advised of an incident at Jubilee Street and Coronation Street, Bootle. UIM 1 has been found slumped in a rear alley of Jubilee and Coronation, suffering head injuries and heavily bloodstained. He has been pronounced dead. This will be treated as murder and I will devise startegies around the investigation. It will be run using MIRSAP. Witnesses have been identified, scenes have been identified and further searches will be required to identify forensic opportunities and potential attack site. I will utilises a policy book and outline forensic, H2H, scene, search, telecoms, FLO and media strategies. The deceased is as yet UK. No offender or weapon has yet been identified. A scene has been secured but further discoveries have identified further scenes are probable.  Forensic opportunites will be paramount and serches must be prioritised.
1,20615,4801,20518,The victim has sustained a head injury and is heavily blood stained. The initial assessment and in the absence of any further information would suggest that the deceased has died as a result of the injury. The circumstances surrounding how he came by those injuries are unclear. At this stage the death is unexplained. My initial assessment would be to treat the matter as suspicious until such time as the facts can be established to either support or negate this assessment.<br />The people present at the scene must all be considered significant to the investigation. In the absence of any information to the contrary, they would be treated as significant witnesses.
1,20616,4804,20518,Initial assessment that an unexplained death has occured, initial actions at scene require reviewing and strategies put in place for the investigation, forensic examination and recovery of evidence, communication and media strategy along with a community impact assessment, and key individuals and opinion formers within the community require contacting and informing. As SIO a number of high priority actions are to be raised to secure and preserve evidence, progress the investigation and the identification of the deceased.<br />The deceased has been found with head injuries, the time of death has yet to be established along with any other assocaited scenes, should this not be the location of any offences and the death. Consideration is to be given to this being a &#039;dump site.&#039;
1,20617,4803,20518,u/K victim - death appears to be from head injuries<br />No initial obvious clues as to who/how<br />speacilaist knowledge from lab<br />2 scenes<br />Scene 1 - back jigger - re- visit scene parameters and expand on assessment<br />Scene 2 - ambulance - taking into account it will need to be used asap as emergency vehicle<br />TST - Witness Jenkins<br />Seize clothing, shoes, mobile phone and mouth swab (mouth to mouth)<br />CCTV of area to be saved - parameters to be decided once exam decides upon approx time of death -<br />House to house - Some initial  and visible reassurance req.<br />TST witnesses Jones/Smith - consider hand swabs - who touched phone/made 999 call<br />Busy local area - media interst will be high - speak to FIM re holding statement<br />Staff - compose team

1,20625,4799,20520,1. Forensic Strategy - early recovery of scientific evidence will assist investigation and avoid loss of evidence - maximise opportunities to arrest and detect offence.<br />2. 1,20692,4805,20528,I wish to point out that I find the review process both helpful and supportive. I feel comfortable with the whole process and am glad of the &#039;extra pair of eyes&#039; in case I miss anything. However in order to answer the question, I would have to say the 24hrs review was the most onerous, only on the basis that I am usually very tired, the investigation is still at full throttle and I could do without having to sit down for another two hours briefing someone else about the job that I have briefed a hundred people beforehand about.
1,20693,4804,20528,I don&#039;t have any difficulty with any of the reviews. I view them as an essential part of the investigative process to provide support at each stage and to ensure that all lines of enquiry have been undertaken. One issue within the review process which always raises comment is other ongoing caseload and resource implications, for the investigation team.
1,20694,4800,20528,24 hour stage as this is very early and the SIO may not have possession of all the facts. You may not know who the victim is, CCtV opportuinities have not been explored or possibley downloaded, witnesses identified, cause of death unknown etc. In addition the SIO could be required to attend at Gold/Media meetings etc.
1,20695,4801,20529,The benefit is that where there is accountability, there is responsibility. As a result there will be a driver to the investigation.<br />In terms of the downside to accountability, I believe that there is a tendancy to use this to apportion blame
1,20696,4799,20528,24 hour review - this is generally held at a time when so much is happening and key lines of enquiry are developing. It is an opportunity to be assessed and reassurred that key lines of enquiry seem to be correct. It is mildly distracting at a busy time but required and necessary<br />The 7 day and 28 day can be delivered in a more structured format. The 7 day review is at a time when more information is available and more meaningful decisions can be reached and assessed. 28 day review is similar
1,20697,4804,20529,I feel the review process provides support to the SIO and in turn provides accountability and transparency should the need arise. The issue with the 24 hour review is arond the SIO having time to sit down with the review officer.
1,20698,4802,20528,All three can be challenging depending upon the investigation. During the early stages of a BCU investigation the SIO is &#039;spinning plates&#039; invariably with miminum staffing levels and having to set, progress and review a number of key strategies. Forensic, scenes, H to H, CCTV, Witesses, Family, Media, Community, suspect / prisoner/ interview, PM and policy all these. A thorough 24 hour review clearly  impacts upon the resilience of the SIO time.<br />Likewise a 7 day review can impact upon SIo time if multiple offenders<br />I support both as they provide support to the SIO and a review porcess at an early stage.<br />28 days review impacts in the requirement to provide all documentaion and responding to questions and interviews from the reviewing team.
1,20699,4803,20529,there is an old saying that in the police you are only one mistake off directing traffic - we do see things with a very critical eye and are quick to make judgments - that&#039;s part of our job<br />Internal criticism OK - with a confidential peer review on your ability methodology etc<br />However - outside criticism from a different department/higher rank who may not know what has actually happenened but has formed an opnion based on selective information - this may harm you professional standing and career impetus/aspirations. It can sometimes be easier to play it safe - not make big decision and hope it doesnt go &#039;tits up&#039; - will it work itself out ? preserve career by maybe waiting to make a decision or blaming someone else
1,20700,4801,20530,I beleive accountability within the police service as a whole is at a reasonable balance. In Merseyside, I would suggest that under a previous regime, there was a tendancy to look towards blame, it is a little early to say whether this will remain the same. I would suggest that where mistakes are made it is much better to use them as learning opportunities as opposed to identifying a scapegoat.
1,20701,4799,20529,Pros - Allows a person to review key decisions and provide an overview.<br />Provides reassurance that decisions are well considered and stand up to scrutiny<br />Allows meaningful dialogue<br />Provides feedback and draws on others experience.<br />Provides transparency<br />Provdes public/organisational reassurance<br />Cons<br />Can&#039;t think of any con&#039;s
1,20702,4805,20529,Pros - Essential. To ensure we retain public confidence in our ability. To retain and share expertise in terms of peer review.  Experiential learning.<br />Cons - Not all those who examine others are credible. Blame culture can be prevelant.
1,20703,4800,20529,The SIO can be blinkered and focused on a line of enquiry and may consider or dismiss other lines. Independent reviews are there to support the SIO and investigation. They provide and independent perspective and fresh pair of eyes and can be supportive in identifying resourcing issues.<br />It also provides transparency and re-assurance to victims families and the community at large that the actions and investigations are continuously reviewed.<br />The negative side of them are that the SIO has to prepare and on some occassions that can occurat a crucial time during the investigation and can detract form the main objective.
1,20704,4803,20530,No - This is a pyramidal system - and you are only as good as your next job. I have rarely found that in the police a view is taken of all your good work over a period of years if you make one big mistake - that is what you are remembered/reknowned for  - again most have knowledge of this and this may mean that caution wins over decisiveness upon occasion.

1,20792,4814,20545,It is sometimes difficult to breakdown and prioritise decision making processes. A lot of what is done is a process to be worked through and at an early stage it is difficult to say one takes priority over any other. Clearly there are some fast tracl action lines of enquiry but they will all need doing as their relevance and importance can increase/decrease quickly dependant on developments elsewhere. Rationale sometimes appears repetetive but these are initial consideartions that will of course develop with the investiagtion as it develops, these cases are by definition dynamic.

1,20795,4813,20545,Normally the process adopted in an investigation is very dynamic and as such is in the first instance very task orientated but against a backdrop of a strategy. The process of reviewing priorities almost becomes second nature (unless resources dictate otherwise) Identifying Top three priorites is not something one would consciously consider but rather one would seek to idenify all the priorities but task out the most important first.
